hedline.hl1: Anonymous Shopping At Stores on the Web

abstract.p: Ecount announces PrivateBuy service, which allows for online shopping without fear of credit card or identity theft (S)

block.p: People concerned about privacy can anonymously send e-mail and surf the Web. But shop online anonymously? That has been nearly impossible, since most Web sites require the buyer's credit card number.

One proposed solution is to provide shoppers with an anonymous debit account that can be used on any e-commerce site that takes credit cards. This is the approach taken by a new service called PrivateBuy.
People concerned about privacy can anonymously send e-mail and surf the Web. But shop online anonymously? That has been nearly impossible, since most Web sites require the buyer's credit card number.

One proposed solution is to provide shoppers with an anonymous debit account that can be used on any e-commerce site that takes credit cards. This is the approach taken by a new service called PrivateBuy.

''This allows users to shop online without the fear of credit card or identity theft,'' said Matt Gillin, co-founder of Ecount, the company that developed the service. Ecount plans to open PrivateBuy for business in the next month.

The service will require people to trust Ecount with their credit card numbers instead. Users will sign up for the debit accounts using the Web or an 800 number, Mr. Gillin said. Each account will have a unique ID number and address, topped with the customer name Private Buyer. Users can write down that information and store it in a safe place or view the account online after typing in a password.

The ID number replaces a credit card number and is designed to be entered as a MasterCard number in online shopping forms. Merchants may not even know, Mr. Gillin said, that their customers are using this private system. The system will not stop shops from displaying banner advertisements related to customers' previous purchases.

PrivateBuy is promising not to divulge customer information but will encrypt and store the information on computers that are not connected to the Internet. Mr. Gillin said the information will be kept in case it is subpoenaed in a criminal investigation.
